lotus.domino
Interface DbDirectory

All Superinterfaces:
Base
public interface DbDirectory
extends Base

Represents the Domino databases on a server or the local computer.

Containment

Contained by: Session

Contains: Database

Creation

You create a new DbDirectory object with getDbDirectory in Session.

See Also

Example

Method Detail

getName

java.lang.String getName()
                         throws NotesException
Read-only. The name of the server whose database directory you are searching.

Usage

This property returns an empty string for DbDirectory objects that represent the local directory.

See Also

Locating a database on a server or the local directory

Session getParent()
                  throws NotesException
Read only. The Domino session that contains a DbDirectory object.

Throws:
NotesException

createDatabase

Database createDatabase(java.lang.String arg1)
                        throws NotesException
Creates a new database, using the server and file name that you specify. Because the new database is not based on a template, it is blank and does not contain any forms or views.

Parameters

String dbfile

The file name of the new database.

boolean open

Indicates whether you want to open the database. Specify true if you want to open the database and false if you do not.

Usage

If you do not open the database, only a subset of its methods are available. See isOpen in Database.

Because the new database is not based on a template, it's blank and does not contain any forms or views.

See Also

Example
Creating, compacting, removing, and replicating a database

Throws:
NotesException

getFirstDatabase

Database getFirstDatabase(int arg1)
                          throws NotesException
Returns the first database from a server or the local directory, using the file type you specify.

Parameters

int type

Indicates the kind of database file you want to retrieve:

  • DbDirectory.DATABASE means any database (NSF, NSG, or NSH file).
  • DbDirectory.TEMPLATE means any template (NTF file).
  • DbDirectory.REPLICA_CANDIDATE means any database or template not disabled for replication.
  • DbDirectory.TEMPLATE_CANDIDATE means any database or template.

Return value

Database

The first database of the specified file type located in the directory, or null if the directory contains no databases of the specified type.

Usage

The returned database is closed. If you do not open the database, only a subset of its methods are available. See isOpen in Database.

Each time you call this method, the database directory is reset and a new search is conducted. If you are searching for template files, for example, a new call to getFirstDatabase with the parameter DATABASE starts searching the directory from the beginning, this time for database files

See Also

Locating a database on a server or the local directory

Throws:
NotesException

getNextDatabase

Database getNextDatabase()
                         throws NotesException
Returns the next database from a server or the local directory, using the file type specified in the preceding getFirstDatabase method.

Return value

Database

The next database located in the directory, or null if there are no more.

Usage

The returned database is closed. If you do not open the database, only a subset of its methods are available. See isOpen in Database.

This method must be preceded in the code by getFirstDatabase.

See Also

Locating a database on a server or the local directory

Throws:
NotesException

openDatabase

Database openDatabase(java.lang.String arg1,
                      boolean arg2)
                      throws NotesException
Opens a database.

Parameters

String dbfile

The file name of the database to open.

boolean failover

If true and the database cannot be opened on the current server, an attempt is made to open it on another server in the cluster (if there is a cluster). The object Server and FilePath properties reflect the server on which the database is opened. For remote (IIOP) access, failover is always false.

Return value

Database

The opened database, or null if the database is not opened.

See Also

Example
Opening a database
NotesError and NotesException classes

Throws:
NotesException

openDatabase

Database openDatabase(java.lang.String arg1)
                      throws NotesException
Opens a database.

Parameters

String dbfile

The file name of the database to open.

boolean failover

If true and the database cannot be opened on the current server, an attempt is made to open it on another server in the cluster (if there is a cluster). The object Server and FilePath properties reflect the server on which the database is opened. For remote (IIOP) access, failover is always false.

Return value

Database

The opened database, or null if the database is not opened.

See Also

NotesException

openDatabaseIfModified

Database openDatabaseIfModified(java.lang.String arg1,
                                DateTime arg2)
                                throws NotesException
Opens a database if it has been modified since a specified date.

Parameters

String dbfile

The file name of the database.

DateTime date

A cutoff date. If one or more documents in the database were modified since this date, the database is opened; if not, it is not opened. Cannot be null.

Return value

Database

The opened database, or null if the database is not opened.

See Also

Example
Opening a database

Throws:
NotesException

openMailDatabase

Database openMailDatabase()
                          throws NotesException
Opens the current user's mail database.

Return value

Database

The opened database, or null if the database is not opened.

Usage

If the program runs on a workstation, openMailDatabase finds the current user's mail server and database in the notes.ini file.

If the program runs on a server, the current user is considered to be the last person who modified the agent (the agent's owner), and openMailDatabase finds the user's mail server and database in the Domino Directory on the server.

If the program is making remote (IIOP) calls to a server, the current user is the user who created the session, and openMailDatabase finds the user's mail server and database in the Domino Directory on the server.

See Also

Example
Opening a database

Throws:
NotesException

openDatabaseByReplicaID

Database openDatabaseByReplicaID(java.lang.String arg1)
                                 throws NotesException
Opens the database with a specified replica ID.

Parameters

String rid

The replica ID of the database that you want to open.

Return value

Database

The opened database, or null if the database is not opened.

recycle

void recycle(java.util.Vector arg1)
             throws NotesException
The recycle method unconditionally destroys an object and returns its memory to the system.

All lotus.domino classes contain the following methods:

public void recycle()
public void recycle(java.util.Vector objects)

In the latter method, the vector contains the Domino Objects to be recycled. This method effectively batches recycle operations and is especially efficient for remote (IIOP) calls.

Java has no knowlege of the heavyweight back-end Domino Objects, only the lightweight Java objects representing them. Garbage collection has no effect on Domino Objects unless you first explicitly recycle them.

If you appear to have memory problems, try recycle but adhere to the following guidelines:

  • Recycle an object only if it is no longer needed.
  • Recycle an object in the same thread in which it is created.
  • Recycling a parent recycles all the children.
  • In Session, call recycle() only after all other threads exit.
  • Where NotesThread.sinitThread() and NotesThread.stermThread() are used, call recycle() before stermThread.

Loops enumerating documents or items are good candidates for recycling.

In a remote (IIOP) environment, recycle releases resources on the server. Although a client-side cache exists, the Java object can no longer communicate with its remote counterpart.

In a remote (IIOP) environment, recycle can be called from any thread on any object.

If you create more than one object to represent the same Domino element, recycling one recycles all. For example:

View v1 = db.getView("All");
View v2 = db.getView("All");
v1.recycle(); // also recycles v2

Results are undefined if you attempt to use a recycled object. No error is guaranteed.

See Also

Supporting components

Specified by:
recycle in interface Base
Throws:
NotesException

             throws NotesException
